The table below shows the average number of hours per week that children aged 5 to 12 spend on different activities in four countries in 2021.

Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

Write at least 150 words.
. The student essay is: Some people think that healthcare should be free for everyone, provided by the government. Other people believe that it is up to each individual to pay for their own medical care. This essay will discuss both sides of this argument and then I will give my opinion. On the one hand, there are strong arguments for free healthcare. Health is a basic human right, and everybody, rich or poor, deserves to get the best medical treatment. If healthcare is free, it means that people are more likely to go to the doctor when they need to, instead of waiting until their condition gets worse because they cannot afford it. This can save lives, and it can also save the government money in the long run because it is cheaper to treat problems early. Also, a healthy population means a more productive workforce, which benefits the economy. Countries like Canada and the UK have free healthcare systems, and they seem to work quite well. The government can pay for it through taxes, which everyone contributes to. However, there are also good reasons why people should pay for their own healthcare. If healthcare is free, then it can lead to long waiting lists and a lower quality of care. When something is free, people may overuse it or not appreciate it. If people have to pay for their healthcare, they might be more careful about their health and make healthier lifestyle choices. Also, some people argue that it is unfair to force taxpayers to pay for other people's healthcare, especially if they are healthy and don't use the system very much. Furthermore, private healthcare can offer more choice and faster access to treatment. In my opinion, a balance is needed. While everyone should have access to basic healthcare, people who can afford it should be able to pay for private insurance to get better or faster care. The government should provide a safety net for those who cannot afford healthcare, but people should also take responsibility for their own health. Maybe a system with both public and private options is the best solution. It is a difficult issue, but ensuring that everyone has access to medical treatment is important.

Write at least 150 words.. The student essay is: The bar chart shows how much it costs to rent an apartment in five cities. It's about the price of one bedroom apartments. Tokyo and Sydney are similar, but Sydney is a little bit higher. Tokyo is two thousand and Sydney is maybe two thousand two hundred. Berlin is the cheapest city. Overall, the chart shows that some cities are very expensive to live in, and some are more affordable. The price of the apartment is different for each city. It is very important to see this information. If someone want to move, they can see this data.

Write at least 150 words.
. The student essay is: The bar chart shows how much fertilizer is used for four different crops in Australia, Japan, and China during 2020. The crops are wheat, rice, corn, and soybeans. The amount is measured in kilograms per hectare. Overall, Japan uses the most fertilizer, and China uses the least. Australia is in the middle. Also, rice needs more fertilizer than the other crops in all the countries. In Australia, wheat uses about 120 kg/ha of fertilizer. Rice is higher, at 140 kg/ha. Corn is a little less, around 110 kg/ha, and soybeans use the least, at 100 kg/ha. Japan uses more fertilizer than Australia. Wheat uses 140 kg/ha, the same as rice in Australia. Rice in Japan needs 170 kg/ha, which is the most for any crop. Corn uses 150 kg/ha, and soybeans use 130 kg/ha. China uses the smallest amount of fertilizer. Wheat uses 100 kg/ha, which is the lowest for wheat. Rice is 110 kg/ha. Corn is just a little bit less than rice, at 105 kg/ha. Soybeans use the least fertilizer in China, and also overall, at 95 kg/ha. Fertilizer use is different in these three countries. Japan uses more maybe they have better farming. China uses the least, so maybe they are using different ways to grow food. It's interesting.

The first chart below shows the distribution of water usage in an average American household.

Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

Write a minimum of 150 words.
. The student essay is: The diagrams illustrate the planned redevelopment of Southwest Airport next year compared to its current layout. Overall, the redeveloped airport will feature significantly expanded retail space and improved passenger flow, primarily achieved through a dedicated sky train connection and a more streamlined security process. Currently, Southwest Airport has separate arrival and departure areas, each with its own security, passport control, and customs facilities. Check-in and bag drop are centrally located. A cafe and ATM are provided, but shopping options appear limited. The proposed redevelopment shows a radical shift. The arrivals and departures areas are still distinct, but the previously separate security and passport control areas are now consolidated into single, larger zones for each. This suggests a centralized and presumably more efficient processing system. A key addition is the Sky Train, connecting directly to the gates, likely reducing walking distances and improving accessibility. Furthermore, the area currently occupied by separate customs facilities has been transformed into a substantial shopping precinct, significantly increasing retail offerings. The cafe and ATM remain, indicating the continued provision of basic amenities. Car hire also seems to be in the same location. In essence, the redevelopment focuses on optimizing passenger experience through streamlined security, enhanced connectivity via the Sky Train, and a substantial expansion of retail opportunities, transforming the airport into a more modern and convenient travel hub.

The chart below shows the changes in employment rates within the technology sector of a specific country from 2015 to 2022.
Summarize the key points and compare the significant changes over the years.

Write a minimum of 150 words.. The student essay is: The prevalence of sugary food and drinks in modern diets is undeniably a cause for concern. The suggestion that these products should be made more expensive to discourage consumption is a complex issue with valid arguments on both sides. While I understand the rationale behind this proposal, I am not entirely convinced it is the most effective solution. On the one hand, increasing the price of sugary items could potentially deter people from purchasing them, especially those on lower incomes. This might lead to a reduction in sugar intake and consequently improve public health outcomes. Governments raise taxes on tobacco and alcohol, and sugary foods could be approached similarly, framing them as detrimental. Higher prices may also encourage food manufacturers to reduce the amount of sugar in their products in order to remain competitive and appeal to health-conscious consumers. In the long run, this could lead to a wider availability of healthier alternatives. However, raising prices is not a foolproof solution and could have unintended consequences. Firstly, it disproportionately affects low-income families, potentially creating a regressive policy where healthier choices become less accessible to those who need them most. Moreover, simply increasing prices might not change entrenched eating habits, and people may instead cut back on other essential goods to afford their sugary fix. Furthermore, it could lead to the development of a black market for cheaper, unregulated sugary products, undermining any potential health benefits. People may also switch to cheaper alternatives that could be just as unhealthy. Ultimately, I believe a more comprehensive approach is needed. While price increases might play a role, they should be combined with other measures such as public awareness campaigns about the dangers of excessive sugar consumption and government subsidies for healthier food options. Education programs in schools and communities can help people make informed choices about their diet, while making fresh fruits and vegetables more affordable can provide a genuine alternative to sugary snacks and drinks. Taxing sugary foods would send a clear message, but it should be implemented alongside programs that ensure healthy diets are accessible and affordable for all.

You should spend about 20 minutes on this task.. The student essay is: The advent of digital books has sparked a debate about the future of reading. Some people believe that e-books have made reading more accessible and convenient, while others argue that they diminish the value of traditional books and the overall reading experience. This essay will explore both sides of this argument before presenting my own view. On the one hand, the rise of digital books has undeniably democratized access to literature. E-readers and tablets can store thousands of books, making them ideal for travel or for people with limited space. Furthermore, digital books are often cheaper than their physical counterparts, and many classic texts are available for free. For individuals with visual impairments, e-books offer features like adjustable font sizes and text-to-speech functionality, opening up a world of reading opportunities that might otherwise be closed to them. Its important to consider these benefits as the digital age continues to advance. However, there are valid concerns about the impact of e-books on the reading experience. Many argue that the tactile pleasure of holding a physical book, turning its pages, and smelling its unique scent, is an essential part of the reading ritual. This sensory experience is simply not replicated by reading on a screen. Moreover, some studies suggest that people comprehend and retain information better when reading from paper compared to digital devices. There's also something special about owning a collection of physical books, building a personal library that reflects one's intellectual journey and creating a tangible connection to the authors and stories they contain. Some may view e-books as disposable, lacking the permanence and gravitas of a cherished book on a shelf. In my opinion, while e-books offer undeniable advantages in terms of accessibility and convenience, they cannot fully replace the unique value of physical books. I believe that both formats can coexist and cater to different needs and preferences. While I appreciate the practicality of having numerous books on a single device when traveling, I still cherish the experience of browsing in a bookstore, discovering new authors, and adding to my collection of physical books. Ultimately, the most important thing is to encourage reading in any format, as literature enriches our lives and broadens our horizons.

The student essay is: The line graph illustrates revenue generated from international tourism across three nations: China, Japan and South Korea, over the period from 2011 to 2018. The revenue is measured in trillions of US dollars. Overall, it’s clear that China experienced the most significant growth in tourism revenue, while South Korea’s income remained comparatively stable. Japan also saw growth, although less dramatic than that of China. In 2011, China’s revenue from international tourism sat at approximately 0.6 trillion USD. This figure then climbed steadily throughout the observed period, eventually peaking at around 1.4 trillion USD in 2018. Japan, on the other hand, began with a revenue of just over 0.4 trillion USD in 2011 and grew to nearly 0.8 trillion USD by 2018. This represents a substantial increase, but is considerably less than China. South Korea's performance differed. Its international tourism revenue fluctuated slightly throughout the years, starting at around 0.35 trillion USD and ending at approximately 0.4 trillion USD. Although some minor rises and dips, it did not display the consistent upward trend of the other two countries. Despite the generally stable trend, South Korea experienced a slight dip around 2015, before recovering to previous levels.

Write a minimum of 150 words.
. The student essay is: Tourism is a big business nowdays. Many contries relay on the money tourists bring. But, is it all good? I think there are both good things and bad things about tourism, and it is important to look at them. One of the main advantages is the economic benefits. Tourism create jobs. Hotels need staff, restaurants need cooks and waiters, and tour companys need guides. Also, tourist spend money in local shops, buying souveniers and other things. This help the economy of the area. For example, in my contry, Thailand, many people work in tourism. Without it, they would have no work, and life would be harder. However, tourism also has its disadvantages. One problem is the environment. Lots of tourist can damage the natural environment. They might drop litter, or damage coral reefs when they go diving. Also, tourist often use a lot of water and electricity, which can put a strain on local resourses. For example, some islands don't have enough water for everyone because tourist use so much for their hotels and swimming pools. Another problems is the cultural impact. Sometimes, tourist don't respect local customs and traditions. They might dress inappropriately, or behave in a way that is offensive to local people. This can lead to tension between tourist and locals. Also, some cultures can be come commercialised, with local traditions changed to appeal to tourist. In conclusion, while tourism can bring economic benefits, it also has negative impacts on the environment and local cultures. Its important to manage tourism carefully so that the benefits outweight the problems. I think that tourism can be a good thing if its done responsable.

The bar chart below shows the number of patents registered in four different industries in Japan between 2010 and 2015.

Summarise the information by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

Write at least 150 words.
. The student essay is: The rise of artificial intelligence presents a double-edged sword. While concerns about widespread job losses are understandable, I largely believe that AI will ultimately create more opportunities than it destroys, provided governments and individuals proactively adapt to the changing landscape. AI will undoubtedly transform society in profound ways, and preparation is key to mitigating the potential downsides. On one hand, it’s undeniable that automation driven by AI will displace workers in certain sectors. Repetitive tasks in manufacturing, data entry, and even customer service are already being automated, and this trend is only likely to accelerate. For example, self-checkout kiosks in supermarkets have already reduced the need for cashiers, and AI-powered chatbots are increasingly handling basic customer inquiries. This naturally leads to anxiety about mass unemployment, which is a valid concern needing addressing. However, framing AI solely as a job destroyer overlooks its potential to unlock new avenues for innovation and employment. The development, implementation, and maintenance of AI systems themselves require a skilled workforce. Moreover, AI can augment human capabilities, allowing us to focus on more creative, strategic, and complex tasks. Consider the field of medicine, where AI can assist doctors in diagnosing diseases, freeing them up to spend more time with patients and develop personalized treatment plans. I see an analogy to the industrial revolution. New jobs rose that no one predicted. In my great grandfathers town, the first factory was seen as a threat by most, until most of them began working there. Governments must play a crucial role in preparing for the long-term impacts of AI. Investing in education and training programs to equip workers with the skills needed for the future economy is paramount. This includes fostering skills in areas like data science, software engineering, and AI ethics, but also creativity, critical thinking, and complex problem-solving – skills that are harder for AI to replicate. Furthermore, governments should explore policies such as universal basic income or enhanced social safety nets to support those who may be displaced by automation, ensuring a more equitable distribution of the benefits of AI. Thinking ahead, we might even be able to shape a new economy driven by creativity and AI. In conclusion, while the potential for job displacement due to AI is real, I am optimistic that AI will ultimately be a catalyst for innovation and new employment opportunities. However, realizing this potential requires proactive measures from governments and individuals to adapt to the changing demands of the future workforce. We should embrace AI's capabilities while simultaneously addressing its potential risks to create a more prosperous and equitable society.

Investing in education and training programs to equip workers with the skills needed for the future economy is paramount. This includes fostering skills in areas like data science, software engineering, and AI ethics, but also creativity, critical thinking, and complex problem-solving – skills that are harder for AI to replicate. Furthermore, governments should explore policies such as universal basic income or enhanced social safety nets to support those who may be displaced by automation, ensuring a more equitable distribution of the benefits of AI. Thinking ahead, we might even be able to shape a new economy driven by creativity and AI. In conclusion, while the potential for job displacement due to AI is real, I am optimistic that AI will ultimately be a catalyst for innovation and new employment opportunities. However, realizing this potential requires proactive measures from governments and individuals to adapt to the changing demands of the future workforce. We should embrace AI's capabilities while simultaneously addressing its potential risks to create a more prosperous and equitable society.

The diagram below shows the evolution of a city park from 20 years ago to the present day.
Summarize the key developments by selecting and reporting the main features, and make comparisons where relevant.

Write at least 150 words.
. The student essay is: The bar chart illustrates the number of patents registered across four distinct industries in Japan from 2010 to 2015. Overall, the Technology sector recorded the highest number of patents, while the Automotive industry showed the lowest. Looking at the details, the number of patents in the Technology sector fluctuated but consistently remained the highest, peaking in 2013 at approximately 135. Although there was a slight dip after 2013, the number remained significantly higher than the other sectors. In contrast, the Automotive sector consistently had the fewest patent registrations throughout the period. Its numbers varied slightly year to year, but stayed below 40. The Pharmaceuticals industry saw a steady increase in patent registrations between 2010 and 2013, also reaching a high point in 2013, although not as pronounced as the Technology sector. After this peak, the numbers levelled off. The Agriculture sector demonstrated a gradual but consistent increase in patent registrations over the six years, reaching around 60 in 2015. This sector showed a more linear growth compared to the other three. In conclusion, the Technology sector led in patent registrations, with significant fluctuations, while the Automotive sector lagged behind. The Pharmaceuticals and Agriculture sectors exhibited more stable trends with Pharmaceuticals peaking and Agriculture showing steady growth. The year 2013 appears to have been a significant year for patent registration in both the Technology and Pharmaceutical industries.
